Info.title: How to Make a Complex Rest API using Angular, Django and PostgreSQL
Info.desc: Explains the process of setting up an Angular frontend with a Django Rest API backend.

Instructions.instruction: We'll build a full-stack web application step-by-step using Angular, Python, Django, and Postgres.
A full video demo of this app can be found on my YouTube channel [here](FILL THIS IN).
Let's get started!

Info.title: Technologies We'll Use
Info.desc: This is the techstack we'll use to make this project

Instructions.instruction: Angular - The JavaScript Framework we'll use to build our user interface.
JavaScript - The scripting language we'll use to add logic to our frontend.
Django - The Python web framework we'll use to help build our Rest Api.
Python - The programming language we'll use to develop our Rest Api.
SQL - The language we'll use to help build and query our database.
PostgreSQL - The database we'll use to store user information.
Visual Studio Code - The code editor we'll use to help us build our project.
PyTest - The Python testing framework we'll use to test our Rest Api.
Jasmine - The built-in Angular testing framework we'll use to test our frontend code.
Github - The platform we'll use for version control and collaborative software development.
Git - The distributed version control system we'll use to track changes to our projects.
Homebrew - MacOS package manager we'll use to install software. Optional to use.

Info.title: Setup Technologies
Info.desc: Explanation of how to setup and verify all technologies.

Instructions.instruction: Verify you have visual studio Code installed by running the following command in a terminal. If it outputs a version number you should have it installed.

Code.FormatCode: code --version
Code.CopyCode: code --version

Instructions.instruction: If you haven't already download Visual Studio Code [Here](https://code.visualstudio.com/download). Download the version that matches your operating system.
Verify that you have Homebrew installed on your computer by running this command in your terminal. If it outputs a version you should have it installed.

Code.FormatCode: brew --version
Code.CopyCode: brew --version

Instructions.instruction: If you don't already have homebrew installed, install it using the following command.

Code.FormatCode: /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
Code.CopyCode: /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

Instructions.instruction: Verify that you have node and npm installed by running the following commands. If they output a version you should be good.

Code.FormatCode:
node -v
npm -v
Code.CopyCode:
node -v
npm -v

Instructions.instruction: If node and npm didn't output a version, download them using homebrew. It's just one command.

Code.FormatCode: brew install node
Code.CopyCode: brew install node

Instructions.instruction: Verify that you have Python3 installed.

Code.FormatCode: python3 --version
Code.CopyCode: python3 --version

Instructions.instruction: If you don't have Python3 installed, download it [here](https://www.python.org/downloads/)
Install the following Python libraries

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-html
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-html

Instructions.instruction: Verify you have the Python packages installed by running the following commands. If it doesn't produce a "WARNING: Package(s) not found" error, you should be good.

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 show django
pip3 show pytest
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 show django
pip3 show pytest

Instructions.instruction: Go to [github.com](https://github.com/) to see if you have an account. If you don't press the "Sign Up" button in the top-right and follow the prompts.
Verify that git is installed by running the following command in a terminal. If it outputs a version you're good.

Code.FormatCode: git --version
Code.CopyCode: git --version

Instructions.instruction: If you don't have git setup follow this instruction set (here)[/CompSci/GitHub#createGHAccount].
Verify that you have PostgreSQL installed by running the following command.

Code.FormatCode: psql --version
Code.CopyCode: psql --version

Instructions.instruction: If the command in step 17 didn't output the version, see the next steps titled "How to Install PostgreSQL". Follow the instruction set that corresponds to your operating system.

Info.title: How to Install PostgreSQL
Info.desc: Explains how to install PostgreSQL on MacOS.

Instructions.instruction: Go [here](https://www.postgresql.org/download/) to see the instructions for how to download PostgreSQL. Press on the card that has the logo of your operating system. For mac you would just install it using the following commands. Make sure to upgrade brew first.

Code.FormatCode:
brew install pkg-config
brew upgrade gh
brew upgrade
brew install postgresql@15
Code.CopyCode:
brew install pkg-config
brew upgrade gh
brew upgrade
brew install postgresql@15

Instructions.instruction: If you get an error that says "error: externally-managed-environment" when you try to run pip3 after upgrading brew, I'd honestly just recommend downloading the latest version of python [here](https://www.python.org/downloads/). Ignore the suggested fixes.
Add PostgreSQL to your PATH

Code.FormatCode:
echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/postgresql@15/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc
Code.CopyCode:
echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/postgresql@15/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

Instructions.instruction: Verify that you have PostgreSQL installed by running the following command.

Code.FormatCode: psql --version
Code.CopyCode: psql --version

Instructions.instruction: If step 21 didn't work your path might be wrong. Run the following command and look for the echo command in the output.

Code.FormatCode: brew reinstall postgresql@15
Code.CopyCode: brew reinstall postgresql@15

Instructions.instruction: If step 21 didn't work, open your ~/.zshrc file by running the following command and then delete the old path. Then press control + o, return/enter, control + x to save your changes

Code.FormatCode: nano ~/.zshrc
Code.CopyCode: nano ~/.zshrc

Instructions.instruction: If step 21 didn't work, run the following command to source your file. Then check that psql is installed.

Code.FormatCode:
source ~/.zshrc
psql --version
Code.CopyCode:
source ~/.zshrc
psql --version

Info.title: Design Your Database Schema
Info.desc: The first thing we'll do is design our database ER and Schema diagrams.

Instructions.instruction: We'll be creating a notes app. We'll have users that each have their own set of notes. Each note will have it's individual attributes.

To design our diagrams we'll use [erdplus.com](https://erdplus.com/). We used this tool in CSC 455 (now CSC 355) so you should be able to login using your UNCW credentials. Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram.

This will be our &Schema Diagram&(/download/NotesSchema.png). Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram. Then name your diagram and select "Relational Schema". When you finished press "Menu" in the top-left. Select "High Resolution (4x normal size)" and then press Save. NOTE: I'm not 100% sure if this diagram is completely accurate.

This will be our &ER Diagram&(/download/NotesSchema.png). Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram. Then name your diagram and select "ER Diagram". When you finished press "Menu" in the top-left. Select "High Resolution (4x normal size)" and then press Save. NOTE: I'm not 100% sure if this diagram is completely accurate.

Info.title: Setup PostgreSQL Database
Info.desc: We'll Setup our PostgreSQL database for our project on MacOS.

Instructions.instruction: Each user in your group will have to setup PostgreSQL on their own computer.
Make sure every user has Postgres installed using the following command to confirm it's installed. If they don't have it installed, follow instructions in the "How to Install PostgreSQL" section

Code.FormatCode: psql --version
Code.CopyCode: psql --version

Instructions.instruction: Now you'll start your Postgres server. First list your brew services. If the status of Postgres is "None" than means your server is NOT running. Copy and record the name of your postgresql database. Mine was "postgresql@15".

Code.FormatCode: brew services list
Code.CopyCode: brew services list

Instructions.instruction: If your server isn't running, start it using the following command. Replace "postgresql@15" with the name from the previous command if it's different.

Code.FormatCode: brew services start postgresql@15
Code.CopyCode: brew services start postgresql@15

Instructions.instruction: Initialize the database cluster using the following command.

Code.FormatCode: initdb /usr/local/var/postgres
Code.CopyCode: initdb /usr/local/var/postgres

Instructions.instruction: Run the following command to confirm your cluster started. If the "status" says running you should be good.

Code.FormatCode: brew services list
Code.CopyCode: brew services list

Instructions.instruction: Login as superuser. You don't have to change any part of the command.

Code.FormatCode: psql -U $(whoami) -d postgres
Code.CopyCode: psql -U $(whoami) -d postgres

Instructions.instruction: Run the following command to see your username.

Code.FormatCode: SELECT current_user;
Code.CopyCode: SELECT current_user;

Instructions.instruction: Run the following command to your list of roles and permissions. Press 'q' to exit.

Code.FormatCode: \du
Code.CopyCode: \du

Instructions.instruction: Create your databases. There will be a development database and a test database. Press 'q' to exit.

Code.FormatCode:
CREATE DATABASE notesapp_db;
CREATE DATABASE notesapp_test_db;
Code.CopyCode:
CREATE DATABASE notesapp_db;
CREATE DATABASE notesapp_test_db;

Instructions.instruction: List your current databases. You should see "notesapp_db" and "notesapp_test_db" in the table.

Code.FormatCode: \l
Code.CopyCode: \l

Instructions.instruction: Now create your users. You will have a super user named "postgres" and a regular user and test user. You can change the usernames and passwords as you wish.
Now run the following command. You should see your new user in your database.

Code.FormatCode: \du
Code.CopyCode: \du

Instructions.instruction: Now exit your Postgres session.

Code.FormatCode: exit
Code.CopyCode: exit

Instructions.instruction: Now test that your URI is working. This isn't a command but this is what it should look like.

Code.FormatCode: postgresql://notes_app_user:notes_team_user_123@localhost/notesapp_test_db
Code.CopyCode: postgresql://notes_app_user:notes_team_user_123@localhost/notesapp_test_db

Instructions.instruction: Now run the following command in your terminal to test your endpoint.

Code.FormatCode: psql postgresql://notes_app_user:notes_team_user_123@localhost/notesapp_db -c "SELECT * FROM Users;"
Code.CopyCode: psql postgresql://notes_app_user:notes_team_user_123@localhost/notesapp_db -c "SELECT * FROM Users;"

Instructions.instruction: Now ping your test database.

Code.FormatCode: psql postgresql://notes_app_test_user:notes_test_user1@localhost/notesapp_test_db -c "SELECT * FROM Users;"
Code.CopyCode: psql postgresql://notes_app_test_user:notes_test_user1@localhost/notesapp_test_db -c "SELECT * FROM Users;"

Instructions.instruction: Again make sure every member of your group does this instruction set.
To recap, this is how you sign into your postgres server.

Code.FormatCode: psql -U postgres
Code.CopyCode: psql -U postgres

Instructions.instruction: Do this after you sign into your server. This is how you sign into your regular database

Code.FormatCode: \c notesapp_db notes_app_user
Code.CopyCode: \c notesapp_db notes_app_user

Instructions.instruction: This is how you sign into your test database

Code.FormatCode: \c notesapp_test_db notes_app_test_user
Code.CopyCode: \c notesapp_test_db notes_app_test_user

Instructions.instruction: See all values in a table. Remember the colon at the end.

Code.FormatCode: SELECT * FROM Users;
Code.CopyCode: SELECT * FROM Users;

Instructions.instruction: These are commonly used PostgreSQL commands.
First make sure everyone in your group has a git setup on their computer. Also make sure everyone has a GitHub account.

Code.FormatCode: git --version
Code.CopyCode: git --version

Instructions.instruction: If you don't have GitHub setup, go (here)[/CompSci/GitHub#createGHAccount] for instructions.
Go to [github.com](https://github.com/) and sign in. Then click on the green "New" button. In the "Create a new repository" form enter the following values.

Code.FormatCode:
Repository name: Django-Rest-Api
Description: Django-Rest-Api using Django and Postgres.

* Do NOT check \"Add a README file\" *

* Press the green \"Create repository\" button *
Code.CopyCode:
Repository name: Django-Rest-Api
Description: Django-Rest-Api using Django and Postgres.

* Do NOT check \"Add a README file\" *

* Press the green \"Create repository\" button *

Instructions.instruction: You should be taken to a new page. In the "Quick setup â€” if you've done this kind of thing before" section you should see the https link. Copy and record this link. Then go to your terminal and run the following command.

Code.FormatCode: git clone YOUR-HTTPS-LINK
Code.CopyCode: git clone YOUR-HTTPS-LINK

Instructions.instruction: Now just add a readme file to your folder and push your changes as a test.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
touch README.md
git add .
git commit -m "Added Readme"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
touch README.md
git add .
git commit -m "Added Readme"
git push

Instructions.instruction: If the previous steps worked, you should be good.
Go back to [github.com](https://github.com/) and sign in. Then click on the green "New" button. In the "Create a new repository" form enter the following values.

Code.FormatCode:
Repository name: Angular-Frontend
Description: Frontend for backend Django api.

* Do NOT check \"Add a README file\" *

* Press the green \"Create repository\" button *
Code.CopyCode:
Repository name: Angular-Frontend
Description: Frontend for backend Django api.

* Do NOT check \"Add a README file\" *

* Press the green \"Create repository\" button *

Instructions.instruction: We'll handle the rest of the Angular-Frontend repository setup later.
Steps 8-13 are optional. Now go back to [github.com](https://github.com/) and open your "Django-Rest-Api" repository. You're going to add your team-members as collaborators.
Click on the "Settings" tab on the right with the gear icon next to it.

On the left-hand bar press on "Collaborators". Then press the green "Add people" tab. In the search bar look up the Github usernames of each of your team members. After you find them press the green "Add *username* to this repository".
After you send the invite tell your team members to check their email. Press the "View invitation" link in the email, then accept on GitHub.
Add them for both your Rest api and frontend repositories.
After that you should be good

Info.title: Django Rest API Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explains the purpose of the various folders and what code they should contain.

Instructions.instruction: django_rest_api/settings.py - The settings for your Django app project.
django_rest_api/urls.py - Where the url patterns for your endpoints will be.
notes_app/management - Where we'll store files to help manage our database.
notes_app/migrations - Where the database schema changes for your models are tracked and stored. These files will be automatically created by Django when you run certain commands.
notes_app/repositories - Where we'll keep functions that directly query our database.
notes_app/services - Where we'll call and add business logic to our repository functions.
notes_app/tests - The tests for our Rest Api.
notes_app/routes - The endpoints of our rest api that will call our service functions. Note that endpoints are called "views" in Django.
notes_app/exceptions.py - The file where our custom errors will be.
notes_app/forms.py - The equivalent to "schemas" in Flask. Allows us to handle user input by accepting JSON and converting it into a database model.
notes_app/models.py - We're the database models (objects) and relationships will be defined.
notes_app/permissions.py - Where the apps custom permissions will be stored.
notes_app/utils.py - Common functions that are reused in various parts of your Rest API.

Info.title: Create your Django Rest API
Info.desc: Explains how to create your Django Rest API and connect it to your PostgreSQL database.

Instructions.instruction: Create your project in the Django-Rest-Api folder.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
django-admin startproject django_rest_api .
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
django-admin startproject django_rest_api .

Instructions.instruction: Download the zappa library. Then start a python session and see what python versions zappa currently supports. If it doesn't raise a RuntimeError when you import it, it means the version of python3 you're using is supported.

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 install zappa

* Start a python session and try importing zappa *
python3
import zappa

exit()
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 install zappa

* Start a python session and try importing zappa *
python3
import zappa

exit()

Instructions.instruction: Find the path to your python version. Copy and record the value for the next step.

Code.FormatCode: which python3.13
Code.CopyCode: which python3.13

Instructions.instruction:
Create your virtual environment. If you don't have python 3.13 installed you can download it [here](https://www.python.org/downloads/).

When I made this zappa didn't support python 3.13. You can see the source code [here](https://github.com/zappa/Zappa). You might need to use 3.12 in the command below if you got a RuntimeError in the previous step.

If your path from the previous step isn't "/usr/local/bin/python3.13", change the third command below to use your path instead.

Using the virtualenv library has multiple benefits over the native python way. It prevents like 3k+ files being modified everytime your download a package.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
pip3 install virtualenv
virtualenv -p /usr/local/bin/python3.13 venv
source venv/bin/activate

clear
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
pip3 install virtualenv
virtualenv -p /usr/local/bin/python3.13 venv
source venv/bin/activate

clear

Instructions.instruction: While your virtual environment is activated install the following libraries.

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install psycopg2
pip3 install psycopg2-binary
pip3 install djangorestframework
pip3 install djangorestframework-simplejwt
pip3 install django-cors-headers
pip3 install python-dotenv
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-django
pip3 install pytest-html

pip install --upgrade pip

clear
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install psycopg2
pip3 install psycopg2-binary
pip3 install djangorestframework
pip3 install djangorestframework-simplejwt
pip3 install django-cors-headers
pip3 install python-dotenv
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-django
pip3 install pytest-html

pip install --upgrade pip

clear

Instructions.instruction: Now run the following command in your folder.

Code.FormatCode: python3 manage.py migrate
Code.CopyCode: python3 manage.py migrate

Instructions.instruction: Create a .gitignore, .gitattributes, and .env file in your project's root.

Code.FormatCode:
touch .gitignore
touch .gitattributes
touch .env
Code.CopyCode:
touch .gitignore
touch .gitattributes
touch .env

Instructions.instruction: Open your "Django-Rest-Api" folder in VSCode. Paste in the following lines in the ".gitignore" file . We haven't created some of these files yet, but that's ok.

Code.FormatCode:
django_rest_api/settings.py

notes_app/management/commands/populate_data.py

.env
Code.CopyCode:
django_rest_api/settings.py

notes_app/management/commands/populate_data.py

.env

Instructions.instruction: Go to your "django_rest_api" folder and open the "settings.py" file. At the top of the file add the following import statements and line.

Code.FormatCode:
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from pathlib import Path

load_dotenv()
Code.CopyCode:
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from pathlib import Path

load_dotenv()

Instructions.instruction: Scroll down in "settings.py" file. Find and delete the "DATABASES" dictionary and replace it with the following.
In the same "settings.py" file and add the following configuration.
In "settings.py" scroll up and add the following values to the end of the "INSTALLED_APPS" list

Code.FormatCode:
'notes_app',
'rest_framework',
'rest_framework_simplejwt',
'corsheaders',
Code.CopyCode:
'notes_app',
	'rest_framework',
	'rest_framework_simplejwt',
	'corsheaders',

Instructions.instruction:
In "settings.py" scroll down and add the following values to the end of the "MIDDLEWARE" list.

THE ORDER MATTERS (in this case). Place the new item item BEFORE the 'django.middleware.common.CommonMiddleware' item which is already in the list.

Code.FormatCode:
'corsheaders.middleware.CorsMiddleware',

# Place the Cors item before this item
'django.middleware.common.CommonMiddleware',
Code.CopyCode:
'corsheaders.middleware.CorsMiddleware',

# Place the Cors item before this item
'django.middleware.common.CommonMiddleware',

Instructions.instruction: In "settings.py" add the following configurations.

Code.FormatCode:
CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS = [
    "http://localhost:4200"
]

CORS_ALLOW_METHODS = [
    "GET", 
    "POST", 
    "PUT", 
    "DELETE", 
    "OPTIONS"
]

CORS_ALLOW_HEADERS = [
    "authorization",
    "content-type",
]

CORS_ALLOW_CREDENTIALS = True
Code.CopyCode:

    "http://localhost:4200"
]

    "GET", 
    "POST", 
    "PUT", 
    "DELETE",

]

CORS_ALLOW_HEADERS = [
    "authorization",
    "content-type",
]

CORS_ALLOW_CREDENTIALS = True

Instructions.instruction: Now open the ".env" file found in the root of your project. Add the following value to the file

Code.FormatCode: DB_ENV=default
Code.CopyCode: DB_ENV=default

Instructions.instruction: Now create your app and a superuser.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
rm db.sqlite3
django-admin startapp notes_app
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py migrate # This will create tables in your default database.

python3 manage.py createsuperuser

* Enter/create your credentials when prompted *
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
rm db.sqlite3
django-admin startapp notes_app
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py migrate # This will create tables in your default database.

* Enter/create your credentials when prompted *

Instructions.instruction: Go to the notes_app folder and open the "models.py" file. Delete its contents and paste in the following code.

Code.FormatCode:
from django.db import models
from django.contrib.auth.models import User

# Model for Notes
class Note(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200, blank=True)
    content = models.TextField(blank=True)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
    updated_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now=True)
    user = models.ForeignKey(User, on_delete=models.CASCADE)  # Reference to Django's built-in User model

    def __str__(self):
        return self.title or "Untitled"

# Model for Tags
class Tag(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=50, unique=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.name

# Model for the Many-to-Many relationship between Notes and Tags
class NoteTag(models.Model):
    note = models.ForeignKey(Note, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    tag = models.ForeignKey(Tag, on_delete=models.CASCADE)

    class Meta:
        unique_together = ('note', 'tag')

    def __str__(self):
        return f'{self.note.title} - {self.tag.name}'
Code.CopyCode:
from django.db import models
from django.contrib.auth.models import User

# Model for Notes
class Note(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200, blank=True)
    content = models.TextField(blank=True)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
    updated_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now=True)
    user = models.ForeignKey(User, on_delete=models.CASCADE)  # Reference to Django's built-in User model

    def __str__(self):
        return self.title or "Untitled"

# Model for Tags
class Tag(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=50, unique=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.name

# Model for the Many-to-Many relationship between Notes and Tags
class NoteTag(models.Model):
    note = models.ForeignKey(Note, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    tag = models.ForeignKey(Tag, on_delete=models.CASCADE)

    class Meta:
        unique_together = ('note', 'tag')

    def __str__(self):
        return f'{self.note.title} - {self.tag.name}'

Instructions.instruction: Now go to notes_app -> management -> commands and open the "populate_data.py" file. Paste in the following code.

Code.FormatCode:
from django.core.management.base import BaseCommand
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from notes_app.models import Note, Tag, NoteTag

class Command(BaseCommand):
    help = 'Populate initial data for the notes app'

    def add_arguments(self, parser):
        parser.add_argument(
            '--database',
            default='default',
            help='Specifies the database to populate. Defaults to "default".'
        )

    def handle(self, *args, **options):
        database = options['database']

        # Create users
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='john_doe', email='john.doe@example.com', password='password123', first_name='John', last_name='Doe')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='jane_smith', email='jane.smith@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Jane', last_name='Smith')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='alice_jones', email='alice.jones@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Alice', last_name='Jones')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='michael_jordan', email='michael.jordan@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Michael', last_name='Jordan')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='tony_stark', email='tony.stark@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Tony', last_name='Stark')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='chris_evans', email='chris.evans@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Chris', last_name='Evans')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='harry_potter', email='harry.potter@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Harry', last_name='Potter')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='james_bond', email='james.bond@example.com', password='password123', first_name='James', last_name='Bond')

        # Create tags
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Work')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Personal')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Travel')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Food')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Books')

        # Create notes for users
        user_2 = User.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        user_3 = User.objects.using(database).get(id=3)

        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Meeting Notes', content='Discussed project milestones and deadlines.', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Shopping List', content='Eggs, Milk, Bread, Butter', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Daily Journal', content='Today I worked on my project and had a great lunch.', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Recipe Ideas', content='Spaghetti Carbonara, Grilled Chicken, Caesar Salad', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Books to Read', content='The Great Gatsby, 1984, To Kill a Mockingbird', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Travel Plans', content='Flight to NYC on Monday, Hotel reservation at Grand Hotel.', user=user_3)

        # Create Note-Tag relationships
        note_1 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=1)
        note_2 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        note_3 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=3)
        note_4 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=4)
        note_5 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=5)
        note_6 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=6)

        tag_1 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=1)
        tag_2 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        tag_3 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=3)
        tag_4 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=4)
        tag_5 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=5)

        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_1, tag=tag_1)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_2, tag=tag_2)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_3, tag=tag_2)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_4, tag=tag_4)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_5, tag=tag_5)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_6, tag=tag_3)

        self.stdout.write(self.style.SUCCESS(f'Successfully populated the {database} database!'))
Code.CopyCode:
from django.core.management.base import BaseCommand
from django.contrib.auth.models import User
from notes_app.models import Note, Tag, NoteTag

class Command(BaseCommand):
    help = 'Populate initial data for the notes app'

    def add_arguments(self, parser):
        parser.add_argument(
            '--database',
            default='default',
            help='Specifies the database to populate. Defaults to "default".'
        )

    def handle(self, *args, **options):
        database = options['database']

        # Create users
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='john_doe', email='john.doe@example.com', password='password123', first_name='John', last_name='Doe')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='jane_smith', email='jane.smith@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Jane', last_name='Smith')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='alice_jones', email='alice.jones@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Alice', last_name='Jones')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='michael_jordan', email='michael.jordan@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Michael', last_name='Jordan')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='tony_stark', email='tony.stark@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Tony', last_name='Stark')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='chris_evans', email='chris.evans@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Chris', last_name='Evans')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='harry_potter', email='harry.potter@example.com', password='password123', first_name='Harry', last_name='Potter')
        User.objects.db_manager(database).create_user(username='james_bond', email='james.bond@example.com', password='password123', first_name='James', last_name='Bond')

        # Create tags
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Work')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Personal')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Travel')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Food')
        Tag.objects.using(database).create(name='Books')

        # Create notes for users
        user_2 = User.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        user_3 = User.objects.using(database).get(id=3)

        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Meeting Notes', content='Discussed project milestones and deadlines.', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Shopping List', content='Eggs, Milk, Bread, Butter', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Daily Journal', content='Today I worked on my project and had a great lunch.', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Recipe Ideas', content='Spaghetti Carbonara, Grilled Chicken, Caesar Salad', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Books to Read', content='The Great Gatsby, 1984, To Kill a Mockingbird', user=user_2)
        Note.objects.using(database).create(title='Travel Plans', content='Flight to NYC on Monday, Hotel reservation at Grand Hotel.', user=user_3)

        # Create Note-Tag relationships
        note_1 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=1)
        note_2 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        note_3 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=3)
        note_4 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=4)
        note_5 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=5)
        note_6 = Note.objects.using(database).get(id=6)

        tag_1 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=1)
        tag_2 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=2)
        tag_3 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=3)
        tag_4 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=4)
        tag_5 = Tag.objects.using(database).get(id=5)

        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_1, tag=tag_1)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_2, tag=tag_2)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_3, tag=tag_2)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_4, tag=tag_4)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_5, tag=tag_5)
        NoteTag.objects.using(database).create(note=note_6, tag=tag_3)

        self.stdout.write(self.style.SUCCESS(f'Successfully populated the {database} database!'))

Code.FormatCode:
from .models import Note

def verify_note_belongs_to_user(note_id: int, user_id: int) -> bool:
    note = Note.objects.filter(id=note_id, user_id=user_id).first()
    return note is not None
Code.CopyCode:
from .models import Note

def verify_note_belongs_to_user(note_id: int, user_id: int) -> bool:
    note = Note.objects.filter(id=note_id, user_id=user_id).first()
    return note is not None

Now go to django_rest_api -> urls.py to setup your endpoints. Do NOT delete the docstring but delete the python code underneath it and replace it with the following.

Code.FormatCode:
from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import path

from notes_app.routes import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('', views.home_page, name='home_page'),
    path('test_db_connection/', views.test_db_connection, name='test_connection'),
    path('get_users/', views.get_all_users, name='get_all_users'),
    path('users/register/', views.register_user, name='register_user'),
    path('users/login/', views.login_user, name='login_user'),
    path('notes/users/<int:user_id>/notes/', views.get_notes_by_user, name='get_notes_by_user'),
    path('notes/tag/<str:tag_name>/', views.get_notes_by_tag, name='get_notes_by_tag'),
    path('notes/users/<int:user_id>/tags/', views.get_all_tags, name='get_all_tags'),
    path('users/<str:username>/', views.get_user_by_username, name='get_user_by_username'),
]

Info.title: Call your Django Rest Api Endpoints
Info.desc: Explains how to call your endpoints using Thunder Client.

Instructions.instruction: First, download the [Thunder Client](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=rangav.vscode-thunder-client) VSCode extension if you haven't already. It's basically postman and it's good for testing endpoints.
After you download and enable Thunder Client you should see a circle and lightning bolt icon on the left side of VSCode. Click on it.
Press the "New Request" button. After you do that, you should see the UI for calling endpoints.
Before starting open a new terminal and run the following commands to start your server.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py runserver
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py runserver

Instructions.instruction: Go back to VSCode and try these GET HTTP requests in Thunder Client. Just paste the link in the field and press the "Send" button. Make sure the HTTP method is set to GET.

Code.FormatCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000

http://127.0.0.1:8000/test_db_connection

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/2/notes

http://127.0.0.1:8000/notes/tag/Work

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/2/tags

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/john_doe
Code.CopyCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000

http://127.0.0.1:8000/test_db_connection

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/2/notes

http://127.0.0.1:8000/notes/tag/Work

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/2/tags

http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/john_doe

Instructions.instruction: Change the method to POST. You can use this data to sign in as an existing user. Paste the JSON in the "JSON" tab text area.
Keep the method as POST. You can register a new user using the following JSON data.

Code.FormatCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/register/

* Enter this data in the JSON Content textarea *


{
  "username": "jimmy_page",
  "email": "jimmy.page@example.com",
  "password": "password123"
}
Code.CopyCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/register/

* Enter this data in the JSON Content textarea *


{
  "username": "jimmy_page",
  "email": "jimmy.page@example.com",
  "password": "password123"
}

Instructions.instruction: Now login in as your Superuser. Keep the method as POST.

Code.FormatCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/login/

* Enter this data in the JSON Content textarea *

{
  "username": "superuser_username",
  "password": "superuser_password"
}



* Copy the value of the access attribute that's output *
Code.CopyCode:
http://127.0.0.1:8000/users/login/

* Enter this data in the JSON Content textarea *

{
  "username": "superuser_username",
  "password": "superuser_password"
}



* Copy the value of the access attribute that's output *

Instructions.instruction: In the output copy the value of the "access" attribute. This will be your JWT authorization token.
Now in the "Headers" tab and an the following HTTP Header. Make sure your check the box next to the new value. Save when you're done using command + s.

Code.FormatCode: Authorization: Bearer YOUR-ACCESS-TOKEN
Code.CopyCode: Authorization: Bearer YOUR-ACCESS-TOKEN

Instructions.instruction: Change the method to GET and paste the following link into the field. We're going to get all users which can only be used by an authorized admin. The admin user should NOT be returned in the list.
Congratulations! You should have now successfully called all your Rest Api endpoints.

Info.title: Add Testing to your Django Rest Api
Info.desc: Explains how to write tests using the pytest framework for your Rest Api.

Instructions.instruction: You should've already installed the necessary libraries in your environment. I included these just in case you haven't already installed them.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate

pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-django
pip3 install pytest-html

deactivate

clear
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate

pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-django
pip3 install pytest-html

deactivate

clear

Instructions.instruction: Open your "Django-Rest-Api" folder in VSCode.
In your root directory open the "pytest.ini" folder. Paste in the following configuration data.

Code.FormatCode:
[pytest]
DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE = django_rest_api.settings
python_files = tests.py test_*.py *_tests.py
Code.CopyCode:
[pytest]
DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE = django_rest_api.settings
python_files = tests.py test_*.py *_tests.py

Instructions.instruction: For future reference, test files can be named using the following conventions. You can change the conventions by modifying the "pytest.ini" file.

Code.FormatCode:
# Covention 1
tests.py 

# Convention 2
test_views.py

# Convention 3
views_tests.py
Code.CopyCode:
# Covention 1
tests.py 

# Convention 2
test_views.py

# Convention 3
views_tests.py

Instructions.instruction: Go notes_app -> tests and open the "tests.py" file. Paste in the following code.
Now go to your terminal and run the tests using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate

pytest
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate

pytest

Instructions.instruction: You can generate an HTML report for your pytests using this command.

Code.FormatCode: pytest --html=report.html
Code.CopyCode: pytest --html=report.html

Instructions.instruction: Open the link next to the text "Generated html report:" in your broswer to see the results. I put an example link below so you know what to look for in the output.

Code.FormatCode: file:///Users/johndoe/Django-Rest-Api/report.html
Code.CopyCode: file:///Users/johndoe/Django-Rest-Api/report.html

Instructions.instruction: Now push your changes to Github. Deactivate will deactivate your virtual environment.

Code.FormatCode:
deactivate

git add .
git commit -m "Added tests"
git push
Code.CopyCode:

git add .
git commit -m "Added tests"
git push

Instructions.instruction: Congratulations! You have now successfully added testing to your Django project!

Info.title: Angular Website Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explanation of the folders that will be used for your frontend code.

Instructions.instruction: src/api - Functions used to call and interact with your backend Rest API endpoints. It's a similar concept to the repository functions interacting with the database.
src/assets - Where you'll put things like your pictures, data, etc.
src/components - Components that you can use in your views. An example would a Note card.
src/lib - Where you'll put the link to where your backend Rest API is being hosted. For this project it should probably be something like "http://127.0.0.1:5000" in development.
src/router - The paths of your application. Used to navigate between pages in your application.
src/services - Business logic for your api functions.
src/stores - A management system you can use to store data and methods you can use to modify and interact with it. It's pretty similar to a class.
src/utils - Common functions that are used across various views.
src/views - The pages of your application. The components will be used in these views.
public - Where to store things like videos and files that the user can download

Info.title: Create your Angular Website
Info.desc: Explains how to create your Angular Website and connect it to your Django Rest API.

Instructions.instruction: Download the Angular CLI tool using npm. Then verify it's installed using the version command.

Code.FormatCode:
npm install -g @angular/cli
ng version
Code.CopyCode:
npm install -g @angular/cli
ng version

Instructions.instruction: If you get an error that says your node version is out of date and doesn't work with Angular, run the following commands. Then rerun the two commands in step 1. If "ng version" outputs the version it means you're good.

Code.FormatCode:
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.2/install.sh | bash
source ~/.nvm/nvm.sh
nvm install --lts
nvm use --lts
nvm alias default lts/*

npm install -g @angular/cli
ng version
Code.CopyCode:
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.2/install.sh | bash
source ~/.nvm/nvm.sh
nvm install --lts
nvm use --lts
nvm alias default lts/*

npm install -g @angular/cli
ng version

Instructions.instruction: Once you have ng installed, let's create a new project. We'll start by creating a new Angular project using the following command.

Code.FormatCode: ng new Angular-Frontend
Code.CopyCode: ng new Angular-Frontend

Instructions.instruction: You will be prompted to answer questions after you run the command from the previous step. You can use "command + k" to clear your terminal after you're done.

Code.FormatCode:
Which stylesheet format would you like to use...? CSS  [ https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS ] 
Do you want to enable Server-Side Rendering (SSR) and...? y

* Give the packages sometime to install *
Code.CopyCode:
Which stylesheet format would you like to use...? CSS  [ https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS ] 
Do you want to enable Server-Side Rendering (SSR) and...? y

* Give the packages sometime to install *

Instructions.instruction: Go back to your empty Angular-Frontend repository on [github.com](https://github.com/) and copy the green HTTPS (or SSH) link. Add the remote git repository to your project using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
rm -rf .git
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial Commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin YOUR-HTTPS-LINK
git push -u origin main
Code.CopyCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
rm -rf .git
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial Commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin YOUR-HTTPS-LINK
git push -u origin main

Instructions.instruction: Run your project using the following commands just to ensure everything is working.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng serve

* Open the localhost link in your browser *
Code.CopyCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng serve

* Open the localhost link in your browser *

Instructions.instruction: After you confirmed that's working we'll setup our file structure.

Code.FormatCode:
ng add @angular/material

mkdir api
mkdir assets
mkdir components
mkdir lib
mkdir router 
mkdir services
mkdir stores
mkdir utils
mkdir views

mv app.routes.ts router

ng generate service api/notesAPI
ng generate service api/userAPI

ng generate component components/NoteCard
ng generate component components/NavBar
ng generate component components/LogoutAlert

ng generate service lib/axios

ng generate service services/notes
ng generate service services/user


ng generate service stores/auth
ng generate service stores/starred

ng generate service utils/DateFormat

ng generate component views/MainPage
ng generate component views/SignIn
ng generate component views/SignUp
ng generate component views/Starred

Instructions.instruction: Download the follow package.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend

ng add @angular/material

Choose a prebuilt theme name, or "custom" for a custom theme:
Azure/Blue


Set up global Angular Material typography styles?
n (no)

Include the Angular animations module?
Do not include

git push

Instructions.instruction: To run and test your website, open two terminals. In the first terminal start your Rest Api using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py runserver
Code.CopyCode:
cd Django-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 manage.py runserver

Instructions.instruction: In the second terminal run your frontend. Open the link in your browser.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng serve
Code.CopyCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng serve

Info.title: Add Testing to your Frontend UI
Info.desc: Explains how to write tests using the Jest framework for your front end.

Instructions.instruction: Angular comes with the built-in Jasmine and Karma testing frameworks. They're super convenient and they're what we'll use for our unit testing in this project.
If you were to run the tests right now you'd get these error for some of the tests.

Code.FormatCode:
NullInjectorError: No provider for HttpClient!

NullInjectorError: No provider for ActivatedRoute!

NullInjectorError: No provider for MatDialogRef!
Code.CopyCode:
NullInjectorError: No provider for HttpClient!

NullInjectorError: No provider for ActivatedRoute!

NullInjectorError: No provider for MatDialogRef!

Instructions.instruction: To resolve these errors, we'll have to change some of the spec testing files.
Open your "Angular-Frontend" project in VSCode. Go to src -> app -> api and open the "notes-api.service.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> api and open the "user-api.service.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app and open the "app.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> components -> note-card and open the "note-card.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> components -> logout-alert and open the "logout-alert.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> components -> nav-bar and open the "nav-bar.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> views -> main-page and open the "main-page.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> views -> sign-in and open the "sign-in.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> views -> sign-up and open the "sign-up.component.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> lib and open the "axios.service.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> services and open the "user.service.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.
Go to src -> app -> services and open the "notes.service.spec.ts" file. Delete it's contents and paste in the following code.

Run your tests using the following commands. After run the two commands, wait a second and your test results should open in your browser. Your terminal will also show the output. All 21 tests should pass.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng test
Code.CopyCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
ng test

Instructions.instruction: After you've confirmed that all 21 tests passed, you can commit your code to Github using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
git add .
git commit -m "Added tests"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
cd Angular-Frontend
git add .
git commit -m "Added tests"
git push

Instructions.instruction: Congratulations! You've added testing to this project.
